page.title: 02BELCHFORD AREA CONT
page.content: remaining. Enclosure of the open fields took place in 1804, and there are now eleven arable farms, varying in size from 50 to 450 acres. There is no dairy farming, but sheep are kept on two farms, bullocks are fattened, and there are intensive pig and poultry units. Hedges are being steadily removed, and fields becoming much larger each year. The viking way footpath passes roughly north to south across the block, and in the north centre of the block is an earthwork (probably a prehistoric round barrow) called Juicetrump Hill. Although entirely agricultural in character, there are now only 25 men in the village employed in agriculture due to intensive mechanisation on the farms. This results in others having to commute to work in places such as Louth, Horncastle and Lincoln.
